title: Identifying Cognitive Distortions
description: Learn to identify common thinking traps that contribute to anxiety and depression

questions.prompt: Which of the following is an example of 'catastrophizing'?
options: If I fail this test, my whole future is ruined
I made a mistake on this report

questions.prompt: All-or-nothing thinking means seeing things as only good or bad with no middle ground.
Which cognitive distortion involves focusing only on negative aspects and ignoring positives?
Describe a recent thought you had that might involve a cognitive distortion:
questions.placeholder: Example: I made a mistake, so I'm a complete failure

questions.prompt: Which distortion assumes you know what others are thinking without evidence?

options: The team project failed because I'm incompetent
Everyone at the party will judge me
I'll definitely fail the interview tomorrow

questions.prompt: How often do you notice cognitive distortions in your thinking?
What might be a more balanced way to view the thought you described earlier?
questions.placeholder: Example: Making a mistake doesn't define my worth...

questions.prompt: Which is NOT a common cognitive distortion?
Recognizing cognitive distortions is the first step to challenging unhelpful thoughts.
